trans-unit.source: System API classes that start with the letter T.
System API classes that start with the letter T.

The TextBuffer class manages arbitrary text file content, and generates and manipulates text.
This class features various string operations, a simple clipboard, and a file interface.
Searches the TextBuffer object for any occurrence of a string expression.
Replaces the content of the TextBuffer object with the content of the clipboard.
Replaces the content of a TextBuffer object with the content of the specified file.
Retrieves the current content of the TextBuffer object.
Returns the string length of the first match in the TextBuffer object.
Returns the character position of the first occurrence of the search string in the TextBuffer object.
Retrieves the number of lines in the TextBuffer object.
public str subStr(int start, int length)
Retrieves part of the content of the TextBuffer object (a substring).
Saves the content of the TextBuffer object to a file.
Returns a string that represents the current object.
Initializes a new instance of the TextBuffer class.
Copies the content of a TextBuffer object to the clipboard.
public void insert(str insertString, int position)
Sets the content of the TextBuffer object to the specified string, overwriting any existing content.
Appends a string to the content of the TextBuffer object.
public void replace(str findString, str replaceString)
public void delete(int start, int length)
Searches the TextBuffer object for any occurrence of a string expression.
A numeric expression that sets the starting position for each search; optional.
If this parameter is omitted, the search starts at the first character position.
A numeric expression that sets the starting position for each search; optional.
If this parameter is omitted, the search starts at the first character position.
true if searchText is found; otherwise, false.
This method performs a textual, case-insensitive comparison by using regular expressions.
For more information, see the match function.
Case-insensitivity can be turned off by using the ignoreCase method.
Regular expressions can be turned off by using the regularExpressions method.
The following example searches the TextBuffer object for all occurrences of a specified string and prints the position at which the match is found.
Replaces the content of the TextBuffer object with the content of the clipboard.
true if the replacement was successful; otherwise, false.
Replaces the content of a TextBuffer object with the content of the specified file.
The encoding option to use; optional.
The encoding option to use; optional.
true if the file operation was successful; otherwise, false.
The following are possible values for the encoding parameter that are supplied by the FileEncoding system enumeration:
If the file operation is unsuccessful, the TextBuffer object remains unchanged.
If an attacker can control input to the fromFile method, a security risk exists.
Therefore, this method runs under Code Access Security.
Calls to this method on the server require permission from the ExecutePermission class.
Make sure that the user has development privileges by setting the security key to SysDevelopment on the control that calls this method.
Retrieves the current content of the TextBuffer object.
A string that contains the content of TextBuffer object.
The TextBuffer can contain new lines, which are then present in the returned string.
Returns the string length of the first match in the TextBuffer object.
The length of the match that is found; 0 (zero) if no match is found.
This method is used as part of a text search (see the find method).
Returns the character position of the first occurrence of the search string in the TextBuffer object.
The position at which the match is found; 0 (zero) if no match is found.
This method is used as part of a text search (see the find method).
Retrieves the number of lines in the TextBuffer object.
The number of lines in the content.
Retrieves part of the content of the TextBuffer object (a substring).
The length of the desired substring.
The length of the desired substring.
A string that contains the specified part of the TextBuffer object content.
When you specify the start position for substring, use 1 for the first character in the content, 2 for the second character, and so on.
Saves the content of the TextBuffer object to a file.
true if the operation is successful; otherwise, false.
If the specified file already exists, it is overwritten without confirmation.
If an attacker can control input to the toFile method, a security risk exists.
Therefore, this method runs under Code Access Security.
Calls to this method on the server require permission from the ExecutePermission class.
Make sure that the user has development privileges by setting the security key to SysDevelopment on the control that calls this method.
Returns a string that represents the current object.
A string that represents the current object.
The default implementation returns the class name of the object.
The method can be overridden in a derived class so that it returns values that are meaningful for that type.
For example, an instance of the SysMethodInfo class returns the method name and type of the method, such as instance or static.
Initializes a new instance of the TextBuffer class.
Copies the content of a TextBuffer object to the clipboard.
Sets the content of the TextBuffer object to the specified string, overwriting any existing content.
A string that contains the new text for the TextBuffer object.
If the TextBuffer object contains any content, it is overwritten by the new content.
Appends a string to the content of the TextBuffer object.
The TextIo class provides functionality for reading and writing text files.
TextIO replaces AsciiIO to provide support for non-ANSI code page file I/O.
The TextIO constructor has an additional optional parameter to set the code page of the file.
The TextIO.new method has an optional argument that specifies the code page of the file.
The default value is UTF-16LE (the Microsoft Windows native Unicode representation).
It is best to use this in most instances, especially if end-users might edit the file in a text editor outside Finance and Operations.
When files are read, TextIO examines the first few bytes of the file for a byte-order mark (BOM) and automatically handles UTF-8, UTF-16LE, and UTF-16BE.
If no BOM is found, the file is assumed to be in the ANSI Code Page (ACP) format.
Gets or sets the character that is used for the field delimiter of an input file represented by a TextIO object.
Gets or sets the character that is used for the record delimiter of an input file represented by a TextIO object.
Gets or sets the record length for an input file.
Gets or sets the character that is used for the field delimiter of an output file represented by a TextIO object.
Gets or sets the character that is used for the record delimiter of an output file represented by a TextIO object.
Reads the next full record from a TextIO object.
Retrieves the status of the last operation performed on a TextIo object.
Writes data to a file represented by a TextIO object.
Writes a Unicode character to a file.
Writes the contents of a container to a file represented by a TextIO object.
public void new(str filename, str mode, \[int codepage\])
Creates a new instance of the TextIO class.
Closes the file and, if data was written, flushes the file buffers to disk.
Gets or sets the character that is used for the field delimiter of an input file represented by a TextIO object.
The character to be used as the field delimiter; optional.
The character used as the field delimiter.
To set the field delimiter for an output file, use
The following example sets the field delimiter for an input file to '\\r\\n'.
Gets or sets the character that is used for the record delimiter of an input file represented by a TextIO object.
The character to be used as the record delimiter; optional.
The character used as the record delimiter.
To set the record delimiter for an output file, use the .
The following example sets the record delimiter to 128.
Gets or sets the record length for an input file.
The record length for the input file; optional.
The record length for the input file.

For files that have a fixed-length format, use the inRecordLength property to ensure that no more than the specified number of characters are read for each record.If the record format is overruled by a specified inRecordDelimiter property value, that is the inRecordDelimiter value is met before the fixed length is read, the record is accepted, and no further data is read.
To ensure that a fixed number of characters are read, set the inRecordDelimiter property value to an empty string.
When no inRecordDelimiter property value is found, the inRecordDelimiter property value is the maximum limit of characters to read.
Set the inRecordDelimiter property value to zero to disable the record length check.
The following example sets the record length to 128.
Gets or sets the character that is used for the field delimiter of an output file represented by a TextIO object.
The character to be used as the field delimiter; optional.
The character used as the field delimiter.
To set the field delimiter for an input file, use the .
The following example sets the field delimiter to ' ' (nothing) for an output file.
Gets or sets the character that is used for the record delimiter of an output file represented by a TextIO object.
The character to be used as the record delimiter; optional.
The character used as the record delimiter.
To set the record delimiter for an input file, use the .
The following example sets the record delimiter for an output file to '\\r\\n'.
Reads the next full record from a TextIO object.
A container that holds one record.
Each entry in the container equals one field in the record.
The definition of the next full record is controlled by the inFieldDelimiter, inRecordDelimiter, and inRecordLength properties.
These properties have default values that allow input and output of the most common formats.
It might be necessary to adjust the properties by using the inFieldDelimiter, inRecordDelimiter, and inRecordLength methods.
The following example reads a record from a file and uses the conpeek function to extract values from the record.
Retrieves the status of the last operation performed on a TextIo object.
The status of the last operation.
The following example throws an error if a file does not exist or if the last operation on the file did not have a status of the IO\_Status::Ok enumeration value.
Writes data to a file represented by a TextIO object.
The values to write to the file.
The values can be of different data types.
true if the write operation succeeds; otherwise, false.
If the write operation fails, can be used to ascertain the cause.
The write method accepts a variable number of arguments.
Each value is put into the output record as a field.
The fields are separated by the field delimiter specified by the .
Each record is separated by the delimiter specified by the .
To write complete containers, use the .
Writes a Unicode character to a file.
true if the write operation succeeds; otherwise, false.
If the write operation fails, the TextIO.status method can be used to check for the cause.
To write multiple values or to write data of different types to a file, use the TextIO.write method.
Writes the contents of a container to a file represented by a TextIO object.
The container that has data to write to the file.
true if the write operation succeeds; otherwise, false.
If the write operation fails, the TextIo.status Method can be used to ascertain the cause.
Entries in the container are separated by the delimiter set by the outFieldDelimiter method.
Containers are separated by the delimiter set by the outRecordDelimiter method.
Creates a new instance of the TextIO class.
The code page number for the character set to be read from or written to the file.
Following are the most common values: For more information about these options, see the list of http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=78282&clcid=0x409.
An error is reported if an invalid code page is requested.
Notice that a code page is reported as "invalid" if it is not installed on the computer (different code pages may be installed on the client and server).
For example, specifying code page 1253 for Greek fails unless the computer's ACP is Greek or Greek language support has been loaded by using Control Panel > Regional Options.
The code page number for the character set to be read from or written to the file.
Following are the most common values: For more information about these options, see the list of http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=78282&clcid=0x409.
An error is reported if an invalid code page is requested.
Notice that a code page is reported as "invalid" if it is not installed on the computer (different code pages may be installed on the client and server).
For example, specifying code page 1253 for Greek fails unless the computer's ACP is Greek or Greek language support has been loaded by using Control Panel > Regional Options.
The code page number for the character set to be read from or written to the file.
Following are the most common values: For more information about these options, see the list of http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=78282&clcid=0x409.
An error is reported if an invalid code page is requested.
Notice that a code page is reported as "invalid" if it is not installed on the computer (different code pages may be installed on the client and server).
For example, specifying code page 1253 for Greek fails unless the computer's ACP is Greek or Greek language support has been loaded by using Control Panel > Regional Options.
A run-time error occurs if the file is accessed with a method that does not correspond to the current opened mode (for example, you try to write to a read-mode file).
If an attacker can control input to the new method, a security risk exists.
This method runs under Code Access Security.
Calls to this method on the server require permission from the FileIoPermission class.
Ensure that the user has development privileges by setting the security key to SysDevelopment on the control that calls this method.
The following table describes some of the more common code pages that might be specified for the \_codePage parameter.
The code page that supports only characters in the user's current language.
The code page is unsuitable for anything that might contain multilingual data or for monolingual data that might be transferred between two systems by using different code pages.
The IBM PC or MS-DOS code page 437.
It is often abbreviated as CP437 and also called DOS-US or OEM-US.
A code page that was used in Western Europe running on operating systems, such as MS-DOS.
The native Unicode representation on Microsoft Windows x86 systems.
Almost all characters are stored as 16 bit.
An identifying byte-order mark is written, examined, and then discarded when the rest of the character is read.
The same as UTF-16LE but byte-swapped.
Used for compatibility with some non-x86 systems, which store bytes from left-to-right instead of low-order to high-order.
An identifying byte-order mark is written first, examined, and then discarded when the rest of the character is read.
Stores Unicode in a byte-streamfriendly way:
European alphabets (including basic diacritics) are 2 bytes per character
Chinese, Japanese, and Korean require 3 bytes per character
This code page is a good choice when a file contains a very high percentage of ASCII, relatively few other characters, and it is important to save space.
For example, .xpo files are stored in UTF-8.
UTF-8 files begin with a 3-byte byte-order mark sequence, which is the first item written.
It is examined, and then discarded when the rest of the character is read.
Stores data in the GB-18030 character representation that is required by the Chinese government.

These files cannot be distinguished from those written in code page 20936 (GB-2312, which is the ACP for Simplified Chinese systems) unless the file contains characters outside the repertoire of GB-2312.
The following example creates a TextIO object to access a file that is named filename in read mode by using code page 850 encoding.
Closes the file and, if data was written, flushes the file buffers to disk.
The TextIO object is usually finalized by leaving the scope.
The finalize method is not usually directly called.
Output written to the file is not valid until the TextIO object is finalized.
The TreeNode class retrieves and represents any node in the Application Object Tree (AOT).
This class, and the classes that extend it, enable you to create, read, update, and delete X++ code and metadata.
Make sure that the user has access to the development security key (SysDevelopment) before calling this API or APIs that are derived from this class.
The TreeNode class can be used to get a handle to any node in the AOT.
The TreeNode class is a generic class in that it can be a reference to any type of node in the AOT.
In addition to providing access to some of the functions on the shortcut menu of the AOT, this class also contains methods that are used to maneuver in the tree.
The TreeNodeTraverser class is also useful in navigating in the AOT.
The TreeNode::findNode and TreeNode::rootNode methods return a treeNode object from which you can maneuver to any other node.

Retrieves the value of the UtilFileType enumeration type for the TreeNode object.
The UtilFileType indicates which kind of file the application object is stored in.
The value of the UtilFileType enumeration for the tree node.
The possible values are in the following list.
UtilFileType::Application means that the element is stored in the .aod file (form, report, query, table, and so on).
UtilFileType::ApplicationCodeDocumentationmeans that the element is stored in the .add file.
UtilFileType::ApplicationHelp means that the element is stored in the .ahd file.
UtilFileType::KernelHelp means that the element is stored in the .akh file.
The following example finds a TreeNode object of each UtilFileType, and then prints the path of the UtilFileType to the Infolog.

If no argument is passed, the new node name is determined by the child node type.
The string that contains the name of the new element.
If no argument is passed, the new node name is determined by the child node type.
For example, if the TreeNode has forms as children, calling this method without an argument will return "Form1".
If the tree node has several child node types, the method returns the string "object".
The following call to Treenode.newObjectName returns "object" because the data dictionary node has children that represent several object types.

The requested TreeNode object or nullNothingnullptrunita null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) if no node with the specified path exists.
Another way of getting a TreeNode object is by using the Info.getNode method.
An important difference between the two methods is that the Info.getNode method will give you a node that is detached from the AOT, whereas the findNode method will return the node in the AOT.
This means that the node that is returned by the Info.getNode method will not have a parent node, whereas the one returned by the findNode method will have a parent node.
The following example retrieves the name of the tree node that is found the TreeNode::findNode method is called.
This example checks whether the user has the required security key before it calls the TreeNode.findNode method.
Determines whether the string passed as an argument can be used as a name for a node in the Application Object Tree (AOT).
The string that contains the tree node name to validate.
true if each condition is met; otherwise false.
A candidate name must meet the following conditions:
The first character must be a letter.
It can only contain letters, numbers or an underscore.
It must not evaluate to a token.
This method does not check if an element of the same name already exists.
It only validates that the argument is a valid name for an AOT object.
Duplicate names may not exist within classes, tables, extended data types, or enums.
The following example gives examples of valid and invalid arguments.
Returns the root node of the AOT.
The root node of the AOT.
The method provides similar functionality to the rootNode method.
Usually you do not have to explicitly unload objects, because the garbage collector will do it automatically.
However, because tree nodes are ordinarily linked to the AOT, they are not garbage-collected.
If you run this method on many tree nodes in the same execution, it can be demanding on resources.
You should unload the tree nodes as you go along to give the garbage collector a chance to remove them.
Make sure to remove all references to the tree node and its subnodes before you call this method.
Use the TreeNode.TreeNodeType().isConsumingMemory method to determine if you need to call this method.
Compiles this node and its subtree in the Application Object Tree (AOT).
Refreshes the node with the latest changes to the .aod file.

Therefore, this method runs under Code Access Security.

This example uses the treeNodeExport method to export the ExampleClass class to an .xpo file.

It does not currently direct the written text to a specific line number in the output Message window.
It does not currently direct the written text to a specific line number in the output Message window.
This method is intended to be used to output text so that when the user later double-clicks that line of text in the message window, some action will happen regarding this node.

The TreeNodeIterator class traverses the child nodes of a tree node.
The following example prints the names of all child nodes of the root node.
Retrieves the next element in the list of child nodes.
Resets the iterator so that the next call to the next method returns the first child node in the list.
Retrieves the next element in the list of child nodes.
The next child node in the tree.
Resets the iterator so that the next call to the next method returns the first child node in the list.
The TreeNodeType class retrieves information about types of TreeNode classes.
This class enable you to reflect on a TreeNode class instance.
The reflection information is not specific to an instance of a TreeNode class.
All TreeNode instances with the same NodeType share the same TreeNodeType.
The TreeNode.TreeNodeType method return a treeNodeType object with the reflection informantion.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are consuming memory that needs to be manually released.
Indicates whether instances of this node type support the TreeNode.GetNodeInLayer method.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are decorated with layers in the AOT.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are model-elements.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are root-elements.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are util-elements.
Initializes a new instance of the TreeNodeType class.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are consuming memory that needs to be manually released.
true if tree nodes of this type are consumes memory; otherwise, false.
After working with TreeNode instances of this type it is important to call the TreeNode.TreeNodeRelease method to release any consumed memory.
Failure to do this will result in out-of-memory exceptions.
Do not call the TreeNode.TreeNodeRelease method before all instances of TreeNode classes in the composition hierarchy has been garbage collected.
For example, do not call the TreeNode.TreeNodeRelease() method on MyClass, if you still have a TreeNode instance of MyClass.myMethod.
Indicates whether instances of this node type support the TreeNode.GetNodeInLayer method.
true if tree nodes of this type support the TreeNode.GetNodeInLayer method; otherwise, false.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are decorated with layers in the AOT.
true if tree nodes of this type are decorated with layers; otherwise, false.
Tree nodes of this type support the AOTLayer and AOTLayers methods.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are model-elements.
true if tree nodes of this type are model-elements; otherwise, false.
A model-element is a tree node that is (or can be) persisted in the model store.
For each model-element tree node one record can be found in the ModelElements table in the model store.
Model-elements are visually decorated with the name of the Model they are contained by in the AOT.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are root-elements.
true if tree nodes of this type are root-elements; otherwise, false.
A root-element is the root in a composition hierarchy of tree nodes.
A root-element never has a model-element parent.
Indicates whether instances of this node type are util-elements.
true if tree nodes of this type are util-elements; otherwise, false.
An util-element is a tree node that can be accessed via the UtilElements and UtilIdElements views.
Util-elements are a subset of model-elements.
Initializes a new instance of the TreeNodeType class.
